summary: An email from ECPAT-USA calling for the resignation of U.S. Labor Secretary Alex Acosta, criticizing his role in securing a 2008 plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein that shielded Epstein from federal charges and failed to notify victims. The email references Epstein's 2019 arrest and urges public support for Acosta's removal.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: U.S. Labor Secretary (formerly U.S. Attorney for Miami)
persons.context: Criticized for his role as U.S. Attorney in 2008 in helping Jeffrey Epstein secure a plea deal that avoided federal charges for sexual abuse of children, and for not notifying victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of a 2008 plea deal arranged by Alex Acosta that allowed him to avoid federal charges for sexual abuse of children; arrested again on sex trafficking charges in July 2019.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, helped Epstein secure a plea deal in 2008 that shielded him from federal prosecution for child sexual abuse.

events.title: Epstein Plea Deal
events.description: Then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta helped financier Jeffrey Epstein secure a plea deal that allowed him to dodge federal charges related to sexual abuse and exploitation of children, without notifying victims.

events.title: Epstein Arrest on Sex Trafficking Charges
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on charges of sex trafficking, revealing more victims in multiple cities.

keyFacts: In 2008, then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta helped Jeffrey Epstein secure a plea deal that avoided federal charges for child sexual abuse and exploitation.
The 2008 plea deal failed to involve or notify Epstein's victims.
Epstein was arrested on sex trafficking charges on July 6, 2019, revealing more victims in multiple cities.
ECPAT-USA sent a letter to the White House calling for Acosta's firing due to his role in the Epstein case.
The document criticizes Acosta's judgment and argues his actions prevented survivors from seeking justice.
